subSections.title: Readings
Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|なみだ}}

From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=なみだ|-}}.

Attested in the ''{{w|Nihon Shoki}}'' with the {{w|man'yōgana}} spelling {{ja-l||那瀰多|namita}}. The ''{{w|Kojiki}}'' and ''{{w|Man'yōshū}}'' have {{ja-l||那美多|namita}},<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|5|798}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man5Yos.html#798 here]</ref> and the ''Man'yōshū'' also has later instances where the {{ja-l|多}} (''ta'') was replaced with {{ja-l|太}} (''da''), forming {{ja-l||奈美太|namida}},<ref>{{RQ:Manyoshu|20|4398}}, text [http://jti.lib.virginia.edu/japanese/manyoshu/Man20Yo.html#4398 here]</ref> indicating a phonetic change over time from ''namita'' to ''namida''.

Ultimate derivation {{unknown|ja|nocap=1|sort=なみだ}}. There are interesting phonetic and semantic similarities with {{cog|th|น้ำตา||tear|lit=water + eye}}, overlapping semantically with {{cog|ko|눈물||tear|lit=eye + water}}, perhaps pointing to an ancient prehistoric borrowing. However, such similarities may also be purely accidental.

subSections.title: Etymology 2
Etymology 3
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|なだ}}

Alteration of ''namida'' or ''nanda'' above. Used during the {{w|Edo period}} in the rough informal speech used by the staff and servants of [[samurai]] households, and others of lower social rank.<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref><ref name="DJR">{{R:Daijirin}}</ref><ref name="DJS">{{R:Daijisen}}</ref>
